title.value: Влияние комплексных удобрений с добавками микроэлементов на урожайность многолетних бобово-злаковых травосмесей на осушенной дерново-подзолистой-глеевой легкосуглинистой почве
Impact of complex fertilizers with micronutrient supplements on yield of perennial legume-cereal grass mixtures on sod-podzolic gley light loamy soil

journal.title: Soil Science and Agrochemistry : scientific journal

person.name: Khatulev, I.N., Vitebsk Regional Planning and Surveying Station of Chemicals used in Agriculture, Vitebsk (Belarus)

abstract.value: In course of the research there was studied the effectiveness of nitrogen-phosphorus-potassium fertilizers with micronutrient supplements in growing perennial legume-grass mixtures on sod-podzolic and gley loam soil in the Vitebsk region of the Republic of Belarus. The research was realized in 2010-2012 in the experimental base of the RUE 'Vitebsk Zonal Institute of Agriculture of National Academy of Science of Belarus'. As a result of realized research it was revealed that use of new nitrogen-phosphorus-potassium fertilizer forms with modifying additives (in doses N18-28P39-82K79-165) in the cultivation technology of perennial legume-grass mixtures of the first year, first and second year of use (for the first mowing grass) with the additional application of nitrogen-potassium fertilizer (N25-35K50) under aftermath was efficient farming practices, which provided increase the yield of green mass, dry matter and mineral fertilizer recovery. The influence of standard and complex fertilizers with modifying additives on crop yield of green mass and dry matter of legume-grass mixtures was presented in the table forms. Entering of liquid nitrogen and potassium fertilizer provided the increase in green mass yield on 24 t/ha, dry matter - 10.7 c/ha, payback of 1 kg NPK - 8.1 kg of green mass, 3.6 kg of dry matter in comparison with CAS on a background of PK. As part of legume-grass mixtures of the first year increased the equity participation of legume component (due to alfalfa (Medicago sativa)) to 53.6% (average of three hay crops), the second year of use - up to 63.0% in comparison with herbs of the first year (42%).
